content: I have a hypothesis that inf_cls: InfClosed M and my goal is sInf M ∈ M. Which tatic can I use to close this goal? I searched the document and didn't find any function to close the goal
This is not true, unless M is finite. InfClosed M means that M is closed under binary meets. sInf M is an arbitrary meet.
So how can I say ⊓M in lean?
(by which I mean: do you want it to be closed on non-empty sets? Do you want it to be forced to contain ⊤? ...)

oh wat I mean is that given a set M, ⊓M ∈ M but I can't find the symbol which is equivelent to ⊓M and because ⊓M which is the least upper bound and I thought is it sInf. My definition is wrong from the start sorry about that.

I am trying to recreate the second part from excercise 2 of this: https://www-apr.lip6.fr/~mine/enseignement/mpri/attic/2014-2015/correction.pdf. I am still learning lean4 and order while recreate it in lean4. But I fail to find the equivelent to \meet M

kishou yusa said:

oh wat I mean is that given a set M, ⊓M ∈ M

But Eric's point is that in, for example, a complete lattice, that can't be universally true because the sInf of the empty set is \top.
From the pdf you shared, you want \all S \subset M, sInf S \in M
But why can't I use InfClosed, I see that the definition is almost similar.
oh sInf S \in M is stronger definition than InfClosed
kishou yusa has marked this topic as resolved.

Eric Wieser said:

What would "sInf-closed" mean?

It should mean "is a complete sublattice"
